ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

EVICTIONS FROM HDB ACCOMMODATION
(Particulars)


    1. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for National Development if he will give the number of families who have been evicted from Housing and Develop-

Column: 1152

ment Board accommodation within the last five years upon their failure to pay the monthly rents giving separately the number for each year.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, eight families were evicted from rental flats during the period 1980 to 1984 for rental arrears. The breakdown is as follows: 1980 - 0; 1981 - 3; 1982 - 1; 1983 - 2; 1984 - 2.

Column: 1153



     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, would the Minister - I do not know whether he is in a position to answer this - say for what reason these families were unable to pay the rents for which they were evicted?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: For reasons unknown to us, because jobs in Singapore are easily available. Anybody who is willing to work is able to earn an income sufficient to pay the rent. These figures, in fact, figures do not lie, speak for themselves. HDB has 130,000 rental flats and, for five years, only eight families were in rental arrears and were unable to pay and had to be evicted by HDB. Eight families in five years - Mr Speaker, Sir, I think, the Member for Anson is always imagining that Singapore has a lot of poor people. Just a few days ago he mentioned that three years ago he told the foreign reporters that there were thousands of Singaporeans starving.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: On a point of order. The Minister is grossly distorting what I said. We have distortions from Ministers ad nauseam in this House. What I said was "some people". I did not say "thousands of people". Will you please produce the paper?

     Some hon. Members: Yes.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I didn't say "thousands of people". Produce the paper.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Yes. Mr Speaker, Sir, in fact, I know some people in Singapore are starving. But why are they starving? They are on diet! I know of many people who eat only two meals a day. But it is not because they are so poor that they cannot afford three meals. They skip breakfast because they are afraid of putting on weight.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I am surprised that the Minister says the HDB does not know the reason why these families could not pay their rents. Is the Minister saying that no investigation was made by the HDB before these people were thrown out?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: In every case, an investigation was made and assistance was offered, but the families for reasons known to themselves did not want to pay their rent.

Column: 1154



     Mr Jeyaretnam: May I know from the Minister what assistance was offered to these families?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: The first was to offer them jobs. They usually said that they could not pay the rent because they were unemployed. Then HDB would try to see how it could help them to obtain employment. And the families sometimes said that they were sick, or for various other reasons which HDB investigators thought that if they deserved assistance from the Social Welfare Department, HDB would refer the case to Social Welfare Department. If the families said they were temporarily out of job and were not able to pay the rent, HDB would arrange for them to pay their arrears by instalments and, if they do pay their arrears by instalments, HDB does not evict them,

    In the whole of Singapore, with a population of 21/2 million, HDB had evicted eight families in five years, ie, 1.6 families per year. And the Member for Anson thinks that this is a very serious crime, thinking that an enormous number of people have been evicted. I think Singapore is doing very well since only eight families were unable to pay their rents and had to be evicted. It is a very small number.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Mr Speaker, Sir, would the Hon. Minister inform this House whether, among the eight families who were thrown out of HDB flats, there were families already on social welfare? And among these families, were there able-bodied people, able to work, but not working, or refusing to work?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: On the first point about people on social welfare assistance, the answer is no. I think they received sufficient assistance from the HDB. Usually, if they run into temporary difficulties, HDB will make arrangements to help them. It is the other way. As I mentioned, anybody who is willing to work and is willing to accept any job is able to earn an income to enable him to pay rent.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, is it true that, in the event any family is in rental arrears, then if an MP were to write in to ask for payment by small instalments, would the HDB allow such payment to be made?

Column: 1155



     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is yes. In fact, in many cases HDB allows the rental arrears to be paid by instalments.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, would the Minister produce, in each of these eight cases, the offer of jobs made by the HDB to them?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: HDB tries to assist them, but I do not think that HDB has the responsibility of offering jobs to the people who are in rental arrears.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I thought you said you offered them jobs.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: This is not the HDB's responsibility. But HDB officers, during the investigations, out of their own effort, try to help these people. I have mentioned that usually, during investigations, if the people were to say that they are unemployed, HDB officers would try to see if they could help by offering them jobs. But it is not the HDB's responsibility to offer jobs to anyone who is in rental arrears.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: You said you offered them jobs.

     Encik Yatiman Yusof (Kampong Kembangan): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister how many months in arrears of rent are these people allowed to accumulate before they are evicted?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think it is more than three months, in some cases it is more than six months.

     Encik Yatiman Yusof: May I ask the Minister that in my constituency there is a case of a person who has accumulated arrears of rent by as much as $1,500 for a 3-room rental flat, and yet he is still staying in the HDB flat. Does that not exceed three months' rental?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: I am afraid that has well exceeded a year's rental. As I have said, HDB usually does all sorts of things to try and help these people. To evict a person is not something that HDB would like to do. It is a last resort.

Column: 1156

NUMBER OF FLATS
RECOVERED BY HDB


    2. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for National Development if he will give the number of flats recovered by the Housing and Development Board over the last five years in exercise of its powers under Sections 48(A) and 48(B) of the Housing and Development Act without proceeding in court, giving the number for each year separately.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, for the five-year period from 1980 to 1984, the Board recovered 119 flats in exercise of its powers under Sections 48(A) and 48(B). The breakdown is as follows: 1980 - 5; 1981 - 11 ; 1982 - 29; 1983 - 50; 1984 - 24.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, would the Minister say what was the common reason or cause for the exercise of these powers by the HDB?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, there are several reasons for HDB exercising its powers. For instance, instalment arrears, that means they bought the flat and are not able to pay the instalments; unauthorized subletting and assignment without HDB's approval. Another reason is non-occupation of an HDB flat, in other words, a person has bought the flat but never occupied the flat, and has left the flat vacant. There are also cases of making false declaration in the application; a misuse of premises, such as using the flat as a brothel. Then there are cases of ownership of private property. Under the HDB rules, HDB flat owners are not allowed to own private residential property. But the person did not declare his ownership of a private property, which means he is not qualified to buy HDB flats, and therefore he has bought the flat under false declaration. And there are others who did not serve the bond imposed on them. For example, in every block of flats two or three units would be allocated to Police officers. These Police officers, who have got the priority of allocation, have signed a bond to serve the Government for a certain number of years, and perhaps half-way through the bond they got a better job and resigned from the Police force. This means that they have broken

Column: 1157

the bond and the flats have to be returned to HDB.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, perhaps the Minister may not be able to give these figures now, but I wonder whether he will be good enough to pass on to me the breakdown of these figures.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I will give the hon, Member the figures. I do not have them with me now, but I will send them to him in writing.

VACANT LAND ALONG
ANG MO KIO AVENUE 1


    3. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for National Development what plans he has for the vacant land along Ang Mo Kio Avenue 1 fronting the apartment blocks; and whether it is feasible to convert part of the vacant land into a car park for heavy vehicles as there are insufficient parking lots for such vehicles in Ang Mo Kio New Town.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, the vacant land opposite Ang Mo Kio Avenue 1 is part of Bishan New Town. It is designated as a public open space and is planned to be used as a recreational park.

    The HDB has already provided ample parking facilities for heavy vehicles in Ang Mo Kio New Town. Ang Mo Kio Industrial Park 2 has a centralized lorry park with a total of 303 lots.

RUSTY TAP WATER IN
ANG MO KIO NEW TOWN


    4. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for National Development if he is aware that, despite the periodic flushing of water tanks in Ang Mo Kio New Town, most of the residents are still complaining of rusty tap water; and whether the Housing and Development Board will consider replacing all corroded galvanized iron downfeed pipes to stainless steel pipes and, if so, when.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, unlike some other HDB estates, the 45 blocks in Ang Mo Kio Constituency do not receive water from reservoirs with high chloride content. Rusty water there is probably due to old pipes. The HDB will

Column: 1158

survey each block to ascertain the condition of the pipes. Where necessary, the pipes will be replaced.

     Mr Yeo Toon Chia (Ang Mo Kio)( In Mandarin): Sir, when will such rusty pipes be replaced?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, the HDB has to investigate the pipes first. If the number of pipes is only a few, then the changing of the pipes can be carried out quite quickly. However, if the number of pipes involved is very large, then a tender has to be called, and therefore it will take some time to change these pipes. However, I would like to assure the Member for Ang Mo Kio that the HDB will look into this as a matter of urgency.

     Dr Aline K. Wong (Changkat): Sir, in view of the fact that the rusty water affects quite a number of constituencies, would the Minister consider publishing in the press the planned schedule of replacement of these pipes, where they have been investigated, for the information of the residents of the affected constituencies other than Ang Mo Kio?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think this is agreeable and I will ask the HDB to look into it.

Column: 1158

MULTI-STOREY CAR PARK IN ANG MO KIO NEW TOWN CENTRE


    5. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for National Development whether there are any plans to build a multi-storey car park in Ang Mo Kio Town Centre in view of the acute shortage of parking space.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the HDB is aware of the parking problem in Ang Mo Kio Town Centre. A multi-storey car park, to be completed in 1987, will be built in Ang Mo Kio Town Centre.

     Mr Yeo Toon Chia( In Mandarin): Sir, I would like to know how many cars can be parked in this multi-storey car park?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, I do not have the information on the size of the car park. However, I will give this information to the Member for Ang Mo Kio when I obtain this information from the HDB.

Column: 1159



     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam (Fengshan): Sir, what will be the season parking charge in the multi-storey car park, if this is envisaged, say, in other new towns also?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: The charge is the standard rate for a multi-storey car park. There are two rates, one for an open car park and the other for a multi-storey car park which is at a higher rate. So this higher rate will be the standard rate for the multi-storey car park.

11.20 am

    Head N -

     Dr Augustine Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head N be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead NA-01 Object Group 1100 of the Main Estimates.

    Sir, among the many responsibilities of the Ministry of Finance is one to enhance the effectiveness of the Civil Service through the establishment of appropriate terms and conditions of service, as well as proper training, career development and deployment of staff.

    Sir, in the last few years, much publicity has been given to the rapid promotion that returned scholars have obtained. These scholars are very bright, well educated, but their careers seem to be mapped out right from the start. These are so-called high flyers among the civil servants. And what they have obtained by way of rapid promotion seems to have attracted the envy of many people, especially among the non-graduates and those graduates who have been bypassed in promotion exercises.

    Sir, two days ago, the Minister of State for Defence reassured this House that as far as the Singapore Armed Forces are concerned, Mindef is looking more to the

Column: 1160

performance of the SAF men rather than their paper qualifications. This is very welcome news to those who do not know about it.

    The question that must be raised, Sir, is whether there is a bias in Civil Service promotion criteria. Is the Ministry of Finance concerned also about the career development for ordinary graduates and for non-graduates? In other word's, for officers in middle management and officers in Divisions III and IV. What are the promotional avenues available to civil servants? Is his Ministry looking into their problems of job satisfaction? What are the turnover rates like in the Civil Service in the last few years? What courses are available for self improvement of civil servants?

    This leads me, Sir, to another question, and that is, the problem of the quality of service that our civil servants provide to the public. Do Ministers or their officials make surprise and periodic visits to various departments, especially at service counters, to see for themselves and experience for themselves the quality of service that is provided to the general public? Have there been many complaints about discourtesy on the part of civil servants?

    Related to this, Sir, is the question of whether the Ministry has provided for the political education of civil servants. They are serving the public. They are implementing the policies set by the Government, so they should have some political sensitivity. I know that some years ago, there were such political education courses provided for civil servants, but I have not heard of such courses in recent years.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not have an amendment under this subhead but may I have five minutes?

     The Chairman: Yes, you can have five minutes.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Thank you. I wish to ask the Minister about the Social Development Unit again. Will he inform this House whether foreign graduates, who are not Singapore citizens or even permanent residents, are invited to go on cruises and

Column: 1161

to functions organized by the SDU? And what is the basis or the justification for spending public money on people who are not even permanent residents of this country?

    Secondly, may I ask the Minister whether he would make available the audited expenses spent by the SDU on a cruise, showing how much were the contributions made by the members, and how much was spent by the Unit itself?

     Mr Tan Soo Khoon (Alexandra): Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the point raised by the Member for Whampoa about problems faced by members of the public who deal with civil servants, particularly those who are dealing with matters over the counter. Frequently, I do get complaints from members of the public that those civil servants at the counters are not too helpful, and it often happens that when inquiries are made at counters, passing the buck is a very common thing. I would like to find out from the Minister whether it would be possible to introduce a system of asking our civil servants who deal with members of the public to wear name tags, as is done in Malaysia. I think this might help to some extent to solve all these difficulties.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee (Thomson): Sir, I am speaking on a slightly different topic.

     The Chairman: It does not matter. The whole Head is thrown open for discussion.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to take this opportunity to raise a few comments on the development of fund management expertise in our banking sector.

    Our banking and finance industry is fairly established now. In the Minister for Finance's Budget Statement, he mentioned that the next stage of development of Singapore as a financial centre will be in the promotion of fee-based financial services. This means that we will have to attain a higher level of sophistication in our fund management expertise.

    To foster the advancement of fund management expertise in Singapore, it is necessary to have a sufficiently large critical size of participants. At present, one

Column: 1162

sizable group of corporate treasurers is restrained from full participation in fund management market. These are the corporate treasurers of the statutory boards and the managers of trust funds. Their fund management expertise is constrained because they have to invest in accordance with the Trustees Act. The Act allows them to invest only in certain investments with low risk exposure.

    I have two suggestions to make, Sir. The first is that the Minister for Finance could consider, approving on a case-by-case basis, allowing statutory boards with wellestablished treasury departments to invest a certain proportion of their funds in a wider range of investments. Perhaps the Hon. Minister could look into the case of the UK where, from what I could ascertain, there are two schedules in the UK Trustee Investment Act. These two schedules permit companies which have to abide by the Act to invest in two categories of investments involving different scales of risks.

    My second suggestion, Sir, is that along the same vein, the Hon. Minister may also consider whether the Trustees Act should be reviewed to allow trust funds and other similar institutions which have to abide by the Trustees Act to invest in a wider range of investments.
11.30 am

    As far as I can ascertain, the schedule for permitted investments has not been amended for some years now. The basic objective is to allow more flexibility and opportunities for fund managers to innovate and to think out new investment instruments. If the Minister will consider these proposals, it will lead to a higher rate of return for funds held by statutory boards and trust funds. More importantly, it will lead to a larger pool of funds for investment in Singapore, thereby leading to higher sophistication and expertise in fund management in our banking and finance sector.

     Mr S. Chandra Das (Chong Boon): Sir, in the conduct of our daily business activity or all of our activities, most Singaporeans are required to obtain various form of licences or permits issued by the various

Column: 1163

Government Ministries, departments or statutory boards. Over the years many statutory boards have been set up and a number of new permits and licences have been introduced. Sir, I would like to ask the Hon. Minister for Finance as to the number of licences and permits that are imposed by Government departments and statutory boards in Singapore and, secondly, to ask him whether any steps have been taken or are being taken to review some of these licences and permits so that unnecessary requirements can be eliminated.

     The Minister for Finance, Minister for Education and Minister for Health (Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam): Mr Speaker, Sir, let me first say that I agree fully with the Member for Whampoa concerning the need for proper training and career development in our Civil Service, not only for the senior officers but also for the staff at all levels.

    Members may recall that in a Statement which I made to 'Parliament on the 3rd March, 1982, concerning the Revision of Salaries in the Civil Service, I made the following remarks:

    'The Administrative and Professional services constitute, in a way, the brain of the Civil Service. However, no matter how brilliant the brain, no organization, least of all the Civil Service, can hope to function effectively unless it has a healthy heart and strong arms and legs. The heart of the Civil Service is team work, not only team work between officers in the Administrative and Professional services, whether they are scholars or non-scholars, but also team work between the officers in the senior echelons and the support staff in the Executive service, the Clerical service, Nursing service, etc, who collectively make up the arms and legs of the Civil Service.'

    Sir, nothing has changed or happened in the last three years to give me any reason to change the Statement.

    I would like to inform the House now what steps have been taken by the Government in order to increase training and manpower development so as to improve the competence and the efficiency of staff in the Civil Service.

    First, the creation of the Public Service Division on 1st January, 1983. This created a central focal point for the formulation of personnel development and management policies. Functions and

Column: 1164

responsibilities which were formerly distributed over a number of Government departments were brought together in order to ensure better coordination and direction. Most important, Sir, the formation of the Public Service Division allows for a close nexus between those who formulate personnel and training policies and those who have to implement the policies. The fact, Sir, that the Permanent Secretary of the Public Service Division is also concurrently the Head of the Civil Service is an indication of the importance which Government places on this critical area.

    Also, Sir, in 1982, local staff training and development funds were directly allocated to Ministries by the Ministry of Finance. This was done in order to give the Ministries maximum flexibility to respond to their own training needs. And in line with this policy to give Ministries and departments greater autonomy in the training and career development of their staff, common-user grades were converted into Departmental Services with effect from 1st April, 1984. Under this arrangement Ministries were more willing to train their staff because they then need not run the risk of losing them to other Ministries in regular mass staff posting exercises.

    Prior to 1982, Divisions I and 11 officers accounted for the bulk of training in the Civil Service, Divisions Ill and IV officers accounted for less than 10% of training. I am glad to inform the House that this has now been changed. In the period 1982 to 1984, a total of 9,013 officers have been trained at the Civil Service Institute in various courses. The breakdown of training by divisional status is as follows: 

   Division I              - 42%

   Division II             - 27%

   Divisions III and IV    - 31%
Also, over the same period, 1,579 officers at all levels have undergone Work Improvement Teams training as part of the National Productivity Campaign.

    Sir, in my Addendum to the President's Address, I have stated that the public sector must be staffed by properly qualified, skilled and motivated men and

Column: 1165

women to provide the level and the type of service that will be required and expected. Priority will be placed on staff welfare and training in order to enhance morale and productivity. Training programmes will be reviewed so that they are relevant and help officers achieve their full potential. This, Sir, is a statement of the Ministry's intention, and I can assure the Member for Whampoa that we will fulfil this intention.

    I come next to the point brought up by the Member for Whampoa and also the Member for Alexandra concerning the need for Civil Service staff to be courteous in their dealings with the public. I think this is a commendable trait which should be exercised not only by all civil servants but also by all Singaporeans. I would convey the Members' concern to the Public Service Division and ask them to urge all civil servants to be civil and helpful when they deal with the public. But, Sir, may I also take this opportunity to ask all members of the public to be considerate when they are dealing with civil servants. On many occasions, Sir, it is not the fault of the civil servant that there are occasions for discourteous behaviour or perhaps friction between a member of the public and a civil servant. There must be some give-and-take on both sides. Then we shall all live happily together.

    The Member for Alexandra has suggested that civil servants should wear name tags to identify themselves. I will convey this suggestion to the PSD and ask them to look into it.

    The Member for Whampoa has asked whether political education is still being given to civil servants. I can assure him that this is still going on, and it is included in the courses conducted at the Civil Service Institute.

    I come now to the points raised by the Member for Thomson regarding his suggestion to review the Trustees Act so as to provide some incentive and encouragement to fund management activities in Singapore. This is possible and I will ask the Ministry of Finance (Revenue Division) to do so.

    The Member has also suggested that greater flexibility be given to the treasurers of the statutory boards in order

Column: 1166

to diversify their investments. Sir, I do not agree with this suggestion. Statutory boards are set up for specific purposes: for example, the Port of Singapore Authority to manage and develop our ports; the Public Utilities Board to generate electricity, gas, water, our public utilities, and TAS for the provision of telephone, postal and international telex services. These statutory boards should stick to what they were set up for. And if they have been efficient and are able to run a surplus in their accounts, they should re-invest these surpluses in order to improve their operations so as to lower the cost of services to the public. If they are not able to use up all the money which they have created, they can always return this money to the Ministry of Finance and we will find very useful ways to use these funds.

    Sir, I come now to the remarks of the Member for Chong Boon concerning the licences issued by the Government. Sir, I would like to inform him that Government issues about 6.3 million licences each year comprising 351 different types.
